title: Beyond JavaScript üöÄ
ques: What is **WebAssembly (Wasm)**? Does it replace JavaScript?

answer.content:
No, it works **alongside** JavaScript. 
Wasm is a binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine. It allows you to run languages like **C++, Rust, or Go** on the web at near-native speed.

explanation: JS is the glue, Wasm is the muscle. Use Wasm for heavy tasks (video editing, physics engines).

title: Performance Benefits üèéÔ∏è
ques: Why is Wasm faster than JavaScript for heavy computation?

answer.content:
1.  It is **pre-compiled** binary (faster to decode). 
2.  It is **strictly typed** (no JIT optimization guesswork). 
3.  It has predictable performance characteristics.

explanation: JavaScript JIT is amazing, but it can de-optimize unexpectedly. Wasm is consistent.

title: Rust and Wasm ü¶Ä
ques: Why is **Rust** often the preferred language for writing WebAssembly modules?

answer.content:
Rust has **no Garbage Collector** (unlike Go or C#). 
This results in extremely small Wasm binaries because you don't have to ship a heavy runtime inside the file. It also provides memory safety without overhead.

explanation: Small binary size = Fast load times.

title: Browser Support üåç

answer.content: **No.** It is a W3C standard supported by all major browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) since 2017. It is as standard as CSS.

explanation: Applications like Figma, Google Earth, and Photoshop Web rely entirely on Wasm.

title: Accessing the DOM üå≥
ques: Can Wasm code directly modify the DOM (e.g., `document.getElementById`)?

answer.content:
Currently, **No** (not directly). 
Wasm only does math/logic. To touch the DOM, it must call "imported" JavaScript functions which do the work. (Though the Interface Types proposal aims to fix this).
